channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: As Russia Retreats, a Question Lingers: Who Counts as a Collaborator?
item.description: In towns reclaimed from Russian occupation, Ukrainian officials are working to identify — and punish — those who helped the enemy. It’s dividing some communities.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer, Maria Varenikova and Nicole Tung
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times

item.title: Bad to Worse for Russia
item.description: Vladimir Putin’s call-up of more troops highlights Russia’s continuing struggles in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian solders riding in Kupiansk, Ukraine.

item.title: Appeals Court Frees Justice Dept. to Use Sensitive Files Seized From Trump
item.description: A federal judge had temporarily barred the department from using the records marked as classified in its inquiry into whether the former president illegally retained national defense documents.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage, Glenn Thrush and Alan Feuer
item.media:description: A supporter of former President Donald J. Trump driving through West Palm Beach, Fla.

item.title: Presidential Power to Declassify Information, Explained
item.description: In an interview, Mr. Trump again insisted that “I declassified everything.” He added that as president, “you can declassify just by saying ‘it’s declassified’ — even by thinking about it.”
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage
item.media:description: A list of the items seized when the F.B.I. conducted a search at Mar-a-Lago, former President Donald J. Trump’s club and residence in Palm Beach, Fla.

item.title: Trump Support Remains Unmoved by Investigations, Poll Finds
item.description: Even during peak crises during his presidency, views of him were static. Post-presidency polls have continued the trend.
item.dc:creator: Ruth Igielnik
item.media:credit: Hannah Beier for The New York Times
item.media:description: The loyalty of supporters of Donald J. Trump has long been evident in his favorability ratings.

item.title: Why Omicron Might Stick Around
item.description: Omicron, the 13th named variant of the coronavirus, seems to have a remarkable capacity to evolve new tricks.
item.dc:creator: Carl Zimmer
item.media:credit: Kim Raff for The New York Times
item.media:description: Booster shots administered from a mobile clinic in Salt Lake City this month. One of Covid’s newest subvariants can evade immune responses better than all earlier forms of Omicron.

item.title: Virginia Thomas Agrees to Interview With Jan. 6 Panel
item.description: The committee has sought for months to interview Ms. Thomas, the wife of Justice Clarence Thomas, about her involvement in efforts to overturn the 2020 election.
item.dc:creator: Luke Broadwater and Maggie Haberman
item.category: House Select Committee to Investigate the January 6th Attack
item.media:description: Virginia Thomas with her husband, Justice Clarence Thomas. Her cooperation comes as the Jan. 6 committee is entering its final months of work.

item.title: House Passes Overhaul of Electoral Count, Moving to Avert Another Jan. 6 Crisis
item.description: The legislation, opposed by most Republicans, is a bid to update the law that former President Donald J. Trump tried to exploit on Jan. 6, 2021, to invalidate his defeat.
item.dc:creator: Carl Hulse
item.media:description: Vice President Mike Pence and Speaker Nancy Pelosi presiding over the counting of Electoral College votes in the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021. The legislation would define the vice president’s role as strictly ministerial.

item.title: Bad News From the Fed? We’ve Been Here Before.
item.description: Fed rate increases are causing pain now. But an inside look at the Volcker era shows that conditions were far worse when the Fed tried different tacks to tame inflation.
item.dc:creator: Jeff Sommer
item.media:description: The Federal Reserve chairman, Paul Volcker, spoke to demonstrators protesting high interest rates in Washington in April 1980. Mr. Volcker faced frequent protests early in his term.

item.title: Bank of England Raises Interest Rates to 2.25%
item.description: The central bank is fighting to tame inflation in Britain, which is running near its fastest pace in decades.
item.dc:creator: Eshe Nelson
item.media:description: The British central bank has been fighting high inflation by raising interest rates seven times since December.

item.title: The 25 Most Influential Postwar Women’s Wear Collections
item.description: A group of fashion experts — editors, historians and a designer — convened over Zoom to make a list of the clothes that shaped the world.
item.dc:creator: Nick Haramis, Max Berlinger, Rose Courteau, Jessica Testa and Kin Woo
item.media:description: Looks from the Courrèges collection, published in The New York Times in March 1965.

item.title: The Inside Joke That Became Trump’s Big Lie
item.description: The lie that Trump won the 2020 election has grown so powerful because it is yoked to an older deception: the idea that American politics is a joke.
item.dc:creator: Carlos Lozada

item.title: Moderate Republicans No Longer Have a Home, and It Started With My Defeat
item.description: A former congressman on their decline and how it’s hurting the party.
item.dc:creator: Peter Smith
item.media:credit: Illustration by Sam Whitney/The New York Times; image by Mint Images via Getty Images

item.title: Public Schools Will Be on the Ballot in November
item.description: Some parents have already voted with their feet.
item.dc:creator: Jessica Grose

item.title: Russia’s Putin Is in Trouble
item.description: The ground beneath his feet has started to shift.
item.dc:creator: Marlene Laruelle

item.title: The Midlife Crisis Is Very Real and Nothing to Be Laughed At
item.description: It may be a result of our affluent world. Or it may be biological.
item.dc:creator: Peter Coy
item.media:credit: Illustration by The New York Times; images by CSA Images, via Getty Images

item.title: I Have Worked, Played and Loved in Other Countries Because I Can’t at Home
item.description: In Singapore, queers see progress only from a distance.
item.dc:creator: Joel Tan

item.title: Herschel Walker Says He’s ‘Not That Smart.’ I Believe Him.
item.description: Walker is attempting to lower the bar of the upcoming debate so low so that anyone, even Walker, can clear it.
item.dc:creator: Charles M. Blow

item.title: How Big Were Pandemic Learning Losses, Really?
item.description: Despite the Covid disruption, school test score declines look pretty modest.
item.dc:creator: David Wallace-Wells

item.title: Putin’s Escalation of the War in Ukraine
item.description: President Vladimir V. Putin has announced the mobilization of 300,000 Russians in an attempt to bolster his faltering invasion.
item.dc:creator: Sabrina Tavernise, Nina Feldman, Luke Vander Ploeg, Will Reid, Jessica Cheung, Lisa Chow, John Ketchum, Marion Lozano and Chris Wood
item.media:description: Police officers detained a demonstrator during a rally in Moscow on Wednesday to protest the mobilization. Until now, the Kremlin has insisted that no one would be forced to fight in Ukraine.

item.title: Welcome to Wrexham: It’s the Future
item.description: Rob McElhenney and Ryan Reynolds seem sincere about their investment, emotionally and financially, in a Welsh soccer team. But they are not mere observers in its story.
item.dc:creator: Rory Smith

item.title: Elise Stefanik Says She’s Confident a Republican Wave Is Coming to the House
item.description: Representative Elise Stefanik, the No. 3 House Republican, also spoke about her PAC’s success in backing female candidates, 23 of whom are running in the fall.
item.dc:creator: Blake Hounshell and Annie Karni
item.media:credit: Shuran Huang for The New York Times
item.media:description: Representative Elise Stefanik at an event in June for the newly elected Representative Mayra Flores, right, whose candidacy Stefanik’s political action committee had supported.

item.title: A Girl Survived a Suicide Bombing in Afghanistan. Then She Vanished in Texas.
item.description: Lina Sardar Khil was 3 when she barely escaped a terrorist attack during the fall of Afghanistan. While living in San Antonio, she went out to play — and has not been seen since.
item.dc:creator: Edgar Sandoval and Zabihullah Ghazi
item.category: National Center for Missing and Exploited Children
item.media:credit: Tamir Kalifa for The New York Times
item.media:description: The area near where Lina Sardar Khil disappeared from her family’s apartment complex in San Antonio.

item.title: In India, Debunking Fake News and Running Into the Authorities
item.description: Alt News, an independent website, has emerged as a leading debunker of misinformation in the nation, but highlighting hate speech against minorities has put it on a collision course with the government.
item.dc:creator: Suhasini Raj
item.media:credit: Atul Loke for The New York Times
item.media:description: Alt News staff members in Ahmedabad, India. The site has debunked hundreds of cases of bogus information in India.

item.title: 3-K for All? Adams Retreats From Expanding N.Y.C. Preschool Program.
item.description: Mayor Eric Adams is reassessing how New York City’s so-called 3-K for All program, a top priority of his predecessor, fits into his administration’s strategy.
item.dc:creator: Emma G. Fitzsimmons
item.media:description: A recent protest outside Tweed Courthouse in Lower Manhattan sought to push the Adams administration to support universal preschool for 3-year-olds.

item.title: Europe’s Shrinking Waterways Reveal Treasures, and Experts Are Worried
item.description: Drought combined with extreme heat this summer have painted a dramatic picture of Europe’s drying rivers and reservoirs.
item.dc:creator: Derrick Bryson Taylor
item.media:description: The underwater ruins of the village of Aceredo emerged due to the low water level of the Lindoso reservoir in northwestern Spain.

item.title: Speeding Up Your Daily Walk Could Have Big Benefits
item.description: In the largest study to incorporate activity tracker data, picking up the pace paid dividends for long-term health.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Fairbank
item.media:credit: Yana Paskova for The New York Times

item.title: Cardio and Strength Training May Help You Live Longer, Study Says
item.description: A consensus is building among experts that both strength training and cardio‌ are important for longevity.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Fairbank

item.title: Breaking Up With Peloton
item.description: The stationary bike’s convenience made it a pandemic winner, but some former fans are done working out at home.
item.dc:creator: Holly Burns

item.title: The Eyes Have It in Hew Locke’s Power-Challenging Show
item.description: Over the entrance to the Met are medallion portraits of white, male art heroes. Enter Hew Locke with a timely and pointed message about “Gilt” (or “Guilt”).
item.dc:creator: Holland Cotter
item.media:credit: Artists Rights Society (ARS), New York/DACS, London; Lila Barth for The New York Times

item.title: How to Solve Beginner Crosswords
item.description: Get started solving the Mini, Monday and Tuesday puzzles.
item.dc:creator: Jackie Frere and Isaac Aronow
